Deval Patrick and Barack Obama are both known for their soaring rhetoric. They both soared this morning.
"Tomorrow, the sun will rise over Boston," Obama says. "This special place, this state of grace."
"Bet on it!" Obama says, of next year's marathon.
"These small, stunted individuals who would destroy instead of build," Obama says of perpetrator(s).
"We may be momentarily knocked off our feet," Obama says. "But we'll pick ourselves up...We will finish the race."
"Yes, we will find you," Obama says. "And yes, you will face justice. We will find you, we will hold you accountable."
RT @MrWillRitter: I'm welling up a little bit. "..they picked the wrong city. Not here in Boston. Not here in Boston." - POTUS
"If they sought to terrorize us," Obama says, "It should be pretty clear by now, that they've picked the wrong city to do it."
"You will run again," Obama tells Boston.
"Boston," Obama says, "You're my home."
"You welcomed me as a state senator at a convention when few people could pronounce my name right," Obama says.
"There's a piece of Boston in me," Obama says. "You welcomed me as a law student across the river."
RT @chucktodd: There a lot of Bostonians in the West Wing, POTUS had plenty of folks around to share city pride

"Boston may be your hometown, but we claim it too," Obama says. "It's one of America's iconic cities." It's also a city that likes flattery
Like the local he once was, Obama talks of the "State House Dome," "hopping on the T," and sitting in the Common.
"We will recover and repair," Deval Patrick says. "We will grieve our losses and heal. We will rise, and we will endure."
"Massachusetts invented America," Deval Patrick says, proudly, to applause.
Deval Patrick: "In a dark hour, so many of you showed so many of us, that darkness cannot drive out darkness, as Dr. King said."
"Late that afternoon he checked out of the hospital to help this city, our city," Deval Patrick says of Menino.
"I'm thankful for Mayor Menino," Deval Patrick says, triggering applause in the crowd.

Mayor Menino is often called "mumbles" for his garbled speech. But every word just then seemed clear.
"This is Boston," Mayor Menino says, in closing. "A city with courage, compassion, strength. That knows no bounds."
"I'm telling you, nothing can defeat the heart of this city," Menino says. "Nothing. Nothing can take us down."
